title: Psalms Chapter 39 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 39 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 39 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 39.

questions.question: According to Psalms 39:1, what did David say he would take heed to?
options: His ways so he would not sin with his tongue
His enemies so they would not harm him
His riches so they would not be lost
His prayers so they would be heard
questions.correctAnswer: His ways so he would not sin with his tongue
questions.explanation: Psalms 39:1 states that David said, 'I will take heed to my ways, that I sin not with my tongue.'

questions.question: In Psalms 39:2, what was stirred in David when he held his peace?
questions.explanation: Psalms 39:2 says, 'I was dumb with silence... and my sorrow was stirred.'

questions.question: What did David ask the LORD to make him know in Psalms 39:4?
options: His end and the measure of his days
questions.correctAnswer: His end and the measure of his days
questions.explanation: Psalms 39:4 states, 'LORD, make me to know mine end, and the measure of my days.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 39:5, how long has God made David's days?
questions.explanation: Psalms 39:5 says, 'Behold, thou hast made my days as an handbreadth.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 39:6 teaches that every man walks in a vain show and is disquieted in vain.
questions.explanation: Psalms 39:6 states, 'Surely every man walketh in a vain shew: surely they are disquieted in vain.'

questions.question: In Psalms 39:7, where does David say his hope is?
questions.explanation: Psalms 39:7 clearly says, 'my hope is in thee,' referring to the LORD.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 39:8: 'Deliver me from all my ________.'
questions.explanation: Psalms 39:8 says, 'Deliver me from all my transgressions.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 39:9, why did David keep silent and open not his mouth?
questions.explanation: Psalms 39:9 states, 'I was dumb, I opened not my mouth; because thou didst it.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 39:10 says David was healed from the stroke of the LORD's hand.
questions.explanation: Psalms 39:10 says, 'I am consumed by the blow of thine hand,' indicating suffering, not healing.

questions.question: According to Psalms 39:11, what happens to a man's beauty when corrected for iniquity?
options: It consumes away like a moth
questions.correctAnswer: It consumes away like a moth
questions.explanation: Psalms 39:11 says, 'when thou with rebukes dost correct man... thou makest his beauty to consume away like a moth.'

questions.question: In Psalms 39:12, David describes himself as a ______ with God.
questions.explanation: Psalms 39:12 says, 'for I am a stranger with thee, and a sojourner.'

questions.question: What request does David make in Psalms 39:13?
options: Spare me that I may recover strength
questions.correctAnswer: Spare me that I may recover strength
questions.explanation: Psalms 39:13 states, 'O spare me, that I may recover strength.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 39:3 mentions that David's heart was cold within him while musing.
questions.explanation: Psalms 39:3 says, 'My heart was hot within me, while I was musing.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 39:6, what does man heap up but does not know who will gather?
questions.explanation: Psalms 39:6 says, 'he heapeth up riches, and knoweth not who shall gather them.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 39:1: 'I will keep my mouth with a ______, while the wicked is before me.'
questions.explanation: Psalms 39:1 says, 'I will keep my mouth with a bridle, while the wicked is before me.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 39 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 39 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling to control their speech when faced with temptation. Based on Psalms 39, what practical advice would you share?
options: Keep your mouth with a bridle to avoid sinning with your tongue
Speak freely to express your feelings
Ignore the situation and hope for the best
questions.correctAnswer: Keep your mouth with a bridle to avoid sinning with your tongue
questions.explanation: Psalms 39:1 teaches the importance of guarding one's speech to avoid sinning, especially in the presence of wickedness. This reflects the biblical virtue of self-control and wisdom in speech.

questions.question: How does Psalms 39 encourage believers to view the brevity of life in relation to humility?
options: Recognize that our days are like a handbreadth and that all men are vanity
Focus on accumulating wealth and status
Ignore the fleeting nature of life
Seek to extend life at all costs
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize that our days are like a handbreadth and that all men are vanity
questions.explanation: Verses 4-6 highlight the shortness and frailty of human life, which should lead to humility and dependence on God rather than vanity or pride.

questions.question: When feeling sorrow stirred within, what is a biblical response demonstrated by David in Psalms 39?
options: Hold your peace and be silent initially
questions.correctAnswer: Hold your peace and be silent initially
questions.explanation: Psalms 39:2 shows David being silent and holding his peace even from good, indicating the value of thoughtful restraint and prayerful reflection amid sorrow.

questions.question: A believer asks about the foundation of hope in difficult times. What does Psalms 39 teach about the source of hope?
options: Hope is placed in the LORD
Hope is based on human wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Hope is placed in the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 39:7 directly states that the psalmist's hope is in the LORD, emphasizing trust in God as the foundation for enduring trials.

questions.question: How does Psalms 39 address the issue of dealing with sin and asking for forgiveness?
options: Pray for deliverance from transgressions and not to become a reproach
questions.correctAnswer: Pray for deliverance from transgressions and not to become a reproach
questions.explanation: Verse 8 reveals a humble request for God's deliverance from sin and protection from disgrace, teaching believers to seek forgiveness and restoration.

questions.question: What does Psalms 39 teach about the uncertainty of earthly riches and possessions?
options: People accumulate riches but do not know who will gather them
Wealth is the ultimate goal of life
questions.correctAnswer: People accumulate riches but do not know who will gather them
questions.explanation: Verse 6 points out the vanity and uncertainty in amassing wealth without knowing its lasting value, encouraging contentment and trust in God over materialism.

questions.question: According to Psalms 39, how should believers respond when corrected by God for their iniquity?
options: Recognize that God’s rebukes consume beauty like a moth and acknowledge human vanity
Ignore correction and continue as before
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize that God’s rebukes consume beauty like a moth and acknowledge human vanity
questions.explanation: Verse 11 describes God’s correction diminishing our outward beauty and reminds us of our human frailty, teaching humility and repentance.

questions.question: What practical spiritual discipline is modeled by David’s behavior in Psalms 39:9 when faced with difficult circumstances?
options: Remaining silent because God is sovereign over the situation
questions.correctAnswer: Remaining silent because God is sovereign over the situation
questions.explanation: Verse 9 highlights David’s choice to be silent since he recognizes that God is in control, encouraging trust and patience amid trials.

questions.question: How does Psalms 39 guide believers in prayer when feeling like strangers or sojourners in this world?
options: Cry out to the LORD and ask Him to hear your prayers and not be silent
questions.correctAnswer: Cry out to the LORD and ask Him to hear your prayers and not be silent
questions.explanation: Verse 12 expresses the psalmist’s plea for God to listen amid feelings of being a stranger, teaching believers to seek God earnestly in times of loneliness or difficulty.

questions.question: A believer is weary and seeks strength before the end of their life. What does Psalms 39 advise to pray for in this situation?
options: Ask God to spare you so you may recover strength before departing
questions.correctAnswer: Ask God to spare you so you may recover strength before departing
questions.explanation: Verse 13 shows a prayer for God’s mercy to restore strength before death, teaching reliance on God’s sustaining grace in weakness.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 39 teaches that every man at his best state is altogether vanity.
questions.explanation: Psalms 39:5 clearly states that even at the best state, every man is vanity, emphasizing human frailty and the need for humility.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 39, it is wise to speak immediately when one’s heart is burning with emotion.
questions.explanation: While Psalms 39:3 shows David eventually speaking after his heart was hot, the overall chapter advocates restraint and careful control of speech (verse 1), teaching wisdom in managing emotional responses.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'I said, I will take heed to my ways, that I sin not with my ____.'
questions.explanation: Psalms 39:1 expresses the commitment to guard one's tongue to avoid sinning, highlighting the importance of controlling speech.

questions.question: How does Psalms 39 encourage believers to view their life’s duration in comparison to God’s perspective?
options: Life is short and insignificant like a handbreadth before God
Life is eternal and unending in God’s sight
Life is the same length for all people
Life’s length is not important to God
questions.correctAnswer: Life is short and insignificant like a handbreadth before God
questions.explanation: Verses 4-5 describe life as very brief and frail before God, encouraging believers to live with humility and dependence on Him.

questions.question: What does Psalms 39 teach about the attitude toward accumulating wealth?
options: It is often a vain show and can lead to disquietude
It is the ultimate goal of life
It should be pursued at any cost
questions.correctAnswer: It is often a vain show and can lead to disquietude
questions.explanation: Verse 6 warns that accumulating riches can be vain and cause unrest, urging believers to focus on God rather than material wealth.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 39 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 39.

questions.question: In Psalms 39:4, the psalmist asks the LORD to make him know what specific aspect of his life?
options: The measure of his days and his end
questions.correctAnswer: The measure of his days and his end
questions.explanation: Psalms 39:4 explicitly states, 'LORD, make me to know mine end, and the measure of my days,' highlighting the psalmist's request for understanding of life's brevity and his mortality.

questions.question: Which literary device is most evident in Psalms 39:5 when the psalmist refers to his days as 'an handbreadth' and his age as 'nothing before thee'?
options: Simile comparing man to a lion
Allegory of the land of Israel
questions.explanation: The phrase 'my days as an handbreadth' is a metaphor describing the extremely short span of human life compared to God's eternity, as seen in Psalms 39:5.

questions.question: What theme in Psalms 39:6 reflects a common motif in Ecclesiastes about the futility of human efforts?
questions.explanation: Psalms 39:6 speaks of heaping up riches without knowing who will gather them, which parallels Ecclesiastes' theme about the vanity and fleeting nature of earthly wealth.

questions.question: In Psalms 39:7, where does the psalmist place his hope?
questions.explanation: The psalmist declares in Psalms 39:7, 'my hope is in thee,' directly placing his hope in the LORD rather than in any human or worldly thing.

questions.question: Psalms 39:1 mentions the psalmist's intention to keep his mouth with what metaphorical object?
questions.explanation: Verse 1 uses the metaphor of a bridle, an object used to control a horse, to illustrate controlling speech, especially in the presence of the wicked.

questions.question: What emotion does the psalmist express in Psalms 39:2 when he held his peace even from good?
questions.explanation: Psalms 39:2 states 'my sorrow was stirred' indicating that the silence led to internal sorrow or distress.

questions.question: Which phrase in Psalms 39:11 uses imagery of decay to describe the effect of divine rebuke?
options: Beauty to consume away like a moth
Strength to rise like a lion
Joy to overflow like a river
Wisdom to grow like a tree
questions.correctAnswer: Beauty to consume away like a moth
questions.explanation: The verse compares the effect of God's correction to beauty being consumed like a moth, symbolizing the fragile and transient nature of human life.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 39:9, the psalmist remained silent because he acknowledged that God was the cause of his affliction.
questions.explanation: Psalms 39:9 states 'I was dumb, I opened not my mouth; because thou didst it,' affirming the psalmist's silence as submission to God's will.

questions.question: In Psalms 39:12, the psalmist refers to himself as a stranger and a sojourner. This motif is common in which other biblical book emphasizing transient life on earth?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:13 also describes believers as strangers and pilgrims on earth, paralleling Psalms 39:12's theme of life's transience and the believer's temporary sojourn.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 39:10 says, 'Remove thy stroke away from me: I am consumed by the ____ of thine hand.'
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly uses the word 'blow' to describe the painful effect of God's discipline on the psalmist.

questions.question: How does the psalmist's request in Psalms 39:13 reflect a common ancient Near Eastern supplication for restoration?
options: He asks to be spared to regain strength before departing life
He demands immediate deliverance without repentance
He calls for vengeance on his enemies
questions.correctAnswer: He asks to be spared to regain strength before departing life
questions.explanation: The plea in Psalms 39:13 to 'spare me, that I may recover strength, before I go hence' fits the ancient motif of seeking mercy to endure suffering before death.

questions.question: In Psalms 39:8, what does the psalmist ask the LORD to prevent him from becoming?
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly asks God not to make him 'the reproach of the foolish,' indicating a desire to avoid disgrace among the unwise.

questions.question: Which psalmist is traditionally credited with authoring Psalms 39 as indicated in verse 1?
questions.explanation: Psalms 39:1 attributes the psalm to David, identifying him as the author.

questions.question: The theme of human frailty in Psalms 39 is closely related to which New Testament passage emphasizing the brevity of life?
questions.explanation: James 4:14 compares life to a vapor that appears and vanishes, paralleling Psalms 39's meditation on life's fleeting nature.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 39 includes an intertextual allusion to God’s discipline as a refining process similar to the imagery in Job 5:17-18.
questions.explanation: The rebuke and correction described in Psalms 39:11 echoes Job 5:17-18 where divine discipline serves to refine and restore, highlighting a shared theological motif.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 39 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 39 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Psalms 39, what does David resolve to do in the presence of the wicked?
options: Keep his mouth with a bridle
questions.correctAnswer: Keep his mouth with a bridle
questions.explanation: Psalms 39:1 states David's resolution to control his speech and avoid sinning with his tongue when the wicked are before him, reflecting self-control and reverence for God. This is consistent with Proverbs 21:23, James 1:26, Ephesians 4:29, and Colossians 4:6 emphasizing guarded speech.

questions.question: What internal condition does David describe in Psalms 39:3 before he speaks?
options: His heart was hot and a fire burned within him
He was calm and at peace
He was filled with joy and thanksgiving
questions.correctAnswer: His heart was hot and a fire burned within him
questions.explanation: Verse 3 reveals David's intense internal turmoil and reflection, which led him to speak. This illustrates the biblical theme of heartfelt meditation and prayer (Psalm 39:3; Jeremiah 20:9; Ecclesiastes 5:2; Romans 7:15; James 5:16).

questions.question: According to Psalms 39:4, what does David ask the LORD to make him know?
options: His end and the measure of his days
questions.correctAnswer: His end and the measure of his days
questions.explanation: David prays to understand the brevity and frailty of life (Psalms 39:4), which aligns with Ecclesiastes 3:1-2, Job 14:5, James 4:14, and Hebrews 9:27 emphasizing human mortality and God’s sovereign control over life span.

questions.question: What does David say every man is at his best state in Psalms 39:5?
questions.explanation: This verse underscores human frailty and the vanity of human existence apart from God, a theme echoed in Ecclesiastes 1:2, Isaiah 40:6-8, James 4:14, and 1 Peter 1:24-25.

questions.question: What does David recognize about riches in Psalms 39:6?
options: They are heaped up but their final recipient is unknown
They are a sign of God’s favor
questions.correctAnswer: They are heaped up but their final recipient is unknown
questions.explanation: David highlights the futility of accumulating wealth without knowing who will benefit, illustrating the vanity of earthly treasures, consistent with Matthew 6:19-21, Luke 12:15-21, 1 Timothy 6:7-10, and Ecclesiastes 5:10.

questions.question: In Psalms 39:7, where does David place his hope?
questions.explanation: David explicitly states his hope is in God, reflecting the biblical doctrine of trusting in God alone (Psalm 39:7; Psalm 62:5; Jeremiah 17:7; Romans 15:13; Hebrews 6:19).

questions.question: What is David pleading for in Psalms 39:8?
questions.explanation: David asks God to forgive his sins and protect his reputation, emphasizing repentance and the desire for divine mercy (Psalm 39:8; Psalm 51:1-2; Isaiah 1:18; 1 John 1:9; Psalm 103:12).

questions.question: How does David respond to God's discipline according to Psalms 39:9?
options: He was silent and opened not his mouth
questions.correctAnswer: He was silent and opened not his mouth
questions.explanation: David’s silent submission to God’s discipline reflects humility and acceptance (Psalm 39:9; Isaiah 53:7; Job 1:21; Hebrews 12:6; Proverbs 3:11-12).

questions.question: What does David ask God to remove in Psalms 39:10?
questions.explanation: David pleads for relief from God’s chastening hand, recognizing both God’s sovereign discipline and his own suffering (Psalm 39:10; Job 5:17; Hebrews 12:5-11; Psalm 94:12; Proverbs 3:11-12).

questions.question: According to Psalms 39:11, what happens when God corrects man for iniquity?
options: His beauty consumes away like a moth
questions.correctAnswer: His beauty consumes away like a moth
questions.explanation: This verse poetically describes the consuming effect of divine correction on human frailty, consistent with Job 13:28, Isaiah 64:6, James 1:2-4, and Hebrews 12:10-11.

questions.question: How does David characterize himself in relation to God in Psalms 39:12?
questions.explanation: David acknowledges his transient status on earth, emphasizing the biblical theme of pilgrimage and dependence on God (Psalm 39:12; Hebrews 11:13-16; 1 Peter 2:11; Genesis 47:9; Philippians 3:20).

questions.question: What is David’s ultimate plea in Psalms 39:13?
options: Spare me that I may recover strength
questions.correctAnswer: Spare me that I may recover strength
questions.explanation: David asks God for mercy to regain strength before passing away, illustrating trust in God’s sustaining grace (Psalm 39:13; Isaiah 40:29; 2 Corinthians 12:9; Psalm 73:26; Philippians 4:13).

questions.question: What theological truth about human life is emphasized repeatedly throughout Psalms 39?
options: The brevity and vanity of human life
The eternal nature of the soul apart from God
questions.correctAnswer: The brevity and vanity of human life
questions.explanation: Psalms 39 repeatedly stresses how transient and vain human life is, a reminder of dependence on God (Psalms 39:5-6,11; Ecclesiastes 1:2; James 4:14; Isaiah 40:6-8; 1 Peter 1:24).

questions.question: Which attribute of God is most clearly expressed in David’s prayer in Psalms 39?
options: God’s sovereignty over life and death
questions.correctAnswer: God’s sovereignty over life and death
questions.explanation: David’s request to know his end and his plea for deliverance highlight God's sovereign control over human life span and circumstances (Psalm 39:4,10; Job 14:5; Hebrews 9:27; Isaiah 46:9-10; Romans 8:28).

questions.question: How does Psalms 39 contribute to the doctrine of human sinfulness and repentance?
options: By expressing sorrow for sin and requesting deliverance from transgressions
By denying the existence of sin
questions.correctAnswer: By expressing sorrow for sin and requesting deliverance from transgressions
questions.explanation: David’s sorrow stirred in silence and his plea for forgiveness in Psalms 39:2 and 8 reflect deep repentance, consistent with Isaiah 6:5, Psalm 51, Romans 3:23, and 1 John 1:9.
